newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: BHP says it's not about to abandon PNG.
newsitem.headline: BHP says it's not about to abandon PNG.

text.p: Australian resources giant The Broken Hill Co Pty Ltd (BHP) said on Thursday it was not considering abandoning crisis-hit Papua New Guinea as a place for future investment.
"We have been in PNG for a long time and we have been there through thick and thin and I don't think this is going to change our particular view," BHP Copper chief executive Jim Lewis said.

BHP shut down a steel processing plant in Papua New Guinea this week after a confrontation between the prime minister and sacked defence force commander plunged the nation into its worst political crisis.
The company also pulled staff and their families out of the capital, Port Moresby, and Lae to the north, but says its 52-percent owned Ok Tedi copper mine has been unaffected.
Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan and his finance and defence ministers stood down on Wednesday to defuse the crisis, which brought angry troops and rioters onto the capital's streets.
Lewis told reporters in Melbourne he was pleased "the matter" seemed to have been resolved constitutionally but wanted to see a complete and swift end to the crisis.
"We don't see a problem with operating with whomever becomes the government in Papua New Guinea and I would certainly be pleased to see the matter resolved expeditiously," Lewis said.
Papua New Guinea will hold a general election in June.
BHP is not in the position now of having to make a decision on any major investments in Papua New Guinea, Lewis said. But he acknowledged concern among international investors.
"The Papua New Guinea situation has given rise to some uncertainty and I'm sure some nervousness eith international investors," Lewis said.
"Our withdrawal of our people out of Port Moresby and Lae should not be misinterpreated as anything other than simply responding to the particular circumstances of the day."
